summary: The appellants, Ben Okeke, Prince Umeh, and Joshua Chuku, were convicted in the Sekondi High Court of conspiracy to commit robbery and robbery under sections 23(1) and 149 of Act 29, and sentenced to 25 years imprisonment on each count, to run concurrently. The Court of Appeal affirmed the conviction and sentence. The appellants appealed to the Supreme Court, raising grounds including non-compliance with sections 187 and 188 of the Criminal and Other Offences (Procedure) Act, 1960 (Act 30), improper amendment of the indictment, misdirection on alibi, failure to take pleas on count 3, error in assessing the time factor between two robberies, and misdirection on reasonable doubt. The Supreme Court found no substantial miscarriage of justice from alleged procedural lapses at committal, noting that statutory statements were taken and considered. The amendment to the indictment was permissible under section 232(1) of Act 30 and no injustice was demonstrated. The court held that the trial judge did not misdirect the jury on alibi or reasonable doubt, and the appellants' failure to give formal alibi notice did not invalidate the trial. The appeal was dismissed.
citations: Section 187, Criminal and Other Offences (Procedure) Act, 1960 (Act 30)
State v Director of Prisons; Ex Parte Schumann [1966] GLR 703
rationaleHighlights: No substantial miscarriage of justice arose from alleged non-compliance with section 187 and 188 of Act 30, as statutory statements were taken and the committal court found sufficient evidence.
Amendment of the indictment was lawful under section 232(1) of Act 30, and no injustice was demonstrated by the appellants.
The trial court did not misdirect the jury on alibi; the appellants failed to give formal notice as required by section 131 of Act 30.
The failure to take pleas on count 3 was not fatal, as the appellants were properly arraigned and the record supports conviction on the charges proved.
The time factor between the two robberies was adequately considered and did not undermine the prosecution's case.
The trial judge's summing up was not flawed, and no misdirection on 'reasonable doubt' occurred.
Evidence supported the conclusion that the appellants were present at both crime scenes, and alibi defence was not properly raised or substantiated.
